results.title: A Filmmaker's Journey
results.brief_description: Superlative documentary tracing the career if one of Hollywood’s most acclaimed and ambitious directors, George Stevens. Unlike other similar documentaries, this is not a mere star studded exercise in hero worship; a real sense of the director’s personality emerges. Excerpts from many of his films are used, including “Giant”, “Shane”, “Gunga Din”, and “The Diary of Anne Frank”. This tribute was written and directed by Stevens’ son.

results.title: A Fatherless village = Mei you ba ba de cun zhuang
results.creator_credit: Lu Ping, Wang Hanchang and Children's Film Studio (China)
results.brief_description:
“Disaster befalling mankind is everlasting. So is the love of human beings.”

The film focuses on the plight of orphaned children, in this case mostly from natural disasters, and the “SOS Villages”, founded in China to provide a more nurturing environment for the traumatised young survivors.

The film opens dramatically with an infant crying out for their mother, amid the destruction of a horrendous volcano eruption. This sets the scene for a collection of young boys and girls, who have been orphaned and sent to one of these “SOS villages”, modeled on the first post-World War II institutions founded by Austrian Doctor Germanile. The village is a collection of several households, with the half-dozen children in each being watched over by a single “auntie”.

The oldest and most rabid of these orphans is Pi Tao, who had to be forcibly separated from his only remaining companion, a mangy dog by the name of Huazi. He enjoys hunting birds (to eat) and is quick to brandish his knife. Living on the street has proven a hard life, and earlier abuse by his grandparents has taught him to assert himself by bullying others and attention win attention with violence. Pi Tao exerts a strong influence as an older role model over the younger children, who are not only young and impressionable but extremely sensitive. They often express this deep psychological trauma at nighttime, which therefore ends up being one of the more lively times of the day. The children suffer from terrifying nightmares, sleepwalk on the roof, and are prone to invite a variety of mischief that ends in the whole village being woken up.

Needless to say, the unrest precipitated by the mental scars of these kids takes a certain toll on their adoptive “aunties”, who through loyalty to their children are often forced to come to loggerheads with the other guardians in the village.

The three aunties featured in the film are neatly stereotyped as; Meng Qiaoling “the strong one”, Yang Qing “The inexperienced — but pretty — youthful one”, and Bai Jin “the homely old widowed one”. As the film progresses their own personal stories unfold, explaining not only their backgrounds and reasons for taking on this role, but also the social stigmas associated with single mothers, adoption, orphans and the lack of a support network for those in desperate need of loving care but are denied it.

The moral of the film, like most others of the period, is that human beings are inherently good, and should therefore be prepared to compromise with the shortcomings and difficulties in associating with others. However, it also touches a much deeper and more fundamental nerve that stretches across all barriers, that society can only function humanely if its people remember their own natural desire to love and be loved, despite the risks of pain engendered through such ventures. With that said, viewers should not expect to be thoroughly entertained, as the film is often rather tedious and dry.
(2 stars - James Donald; June 6, 2011)

results.title: A Fair cop
results.creator_credit: Craig Kirchner, John Cruthers, Steven Salgo, Film Victoria and Seon Film Productions
results.brief_description: A film, for young people to see, that emphasises road safety for cyclists. The film is a fictional dramatisation of a policeman on patrol who encounters some careless riders.

results.title: A Doll's house: by Henrik Ibsen
results.creator_credit: Patrick Garland, Hillard Elkins and Elkins Productions
results.brief_description: Ibsen’s feminist play set is Norway depicts Nora Helmer (Claire Bloom), a woman struggling for independence within her marriage, and against her husband’s will (played by Anthony Hopkins). In the face of male obstinacy and arrogance she sets off in search of her own life and destiny and breaks the shackles which have persisted in treating her as if she were a doll. Cast includes Denholm Elliot, Ralph Richardson and Edith Evans. Another version of Ibsens’s play, directed by Joseph Losey was released in the same year starring Jane Fonda and David Werner.

results.title: From India to Nepal
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

group_works.title: A Distant sound of bugles
group_works.creator_credit: Michael Pearce, Keith Adam, ABC and Royal Nepal Film Corporation

results.title: A Distant sound of bugles
results.creator_credit: Michael Pearce, Keith Adam, ABC and Royal Nepal Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “From India to Nepal”.
Siriparsad Guring returns to his Himalayan village after a 4-year term in a Gurkha regiment. He buys some land to farm and tries to settle back into village life with his wife and young child. After a few months he grows restless, realising that army service has alienated him from his former lifestyle. Narrated by John Gaden.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Pearce, Keith Adam, ABC and Royal Nepal Film Corporation

results.title: A Director talks about his film
results.creator_credit: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films
results.brief_description: A satirical film depicting an interview with an Italian film director, Aldo Altonandino who’s remarks in Italian are translated into English by a deadpanned, uninvolved female interpreter. As he gets carried away by his pseudo-eloquence the translator continues in robot-like fashion. As the camera pulls back, the real director appears explaining his idea for the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Grotenstein, Peter Riegert, Susan Krebs and Prospective Films

results.title: A Handful of dust
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Derek Granger, New Line Cinema and Stagescreen
results.brief_description: Tony and Brenda Last (James Wilby and Kristin Scott Thomas) appear to be the perfect married ccouple - with money, position, a great country house and an adored son, John Andrew. When Tony inadvertently invites John Beaver (Rupert Graves), an idle and penniless young socialite, to stay for the weekend, he sets in motion a series of events which drastically disrupts the course of all their lives. Brenda drifts into an affair with the worthless Mr. Beaver, with disastrous consequences, particularly for Tony, who remains unaware of Brenda’s betrayal until the tragic death of their young son. As Brenda leaves home to take up a precarious life with her lover in London. Tony sets sail with an eccentric explorer on an expedition to the South American rain forests. Lost in the jungle and stricken by fever, Tony is rescued from death by the eccentric Mr. Todd (Alec Guinness) with unexpected and sinister results.

results.title: A guide to landscape painting with Del Newport
results.creator_credit: Leigh Kidd, Robert Dunn, Val Osborn and Coral Coast Video
results.brief_description: Del Newport, prominent teacher and exhibition artist with national and overseas recognition shows step by step the fine detail and intricacies of landscape painting. As she paints a landscape from memory, Del explains what she is doing and why.
results.title_for_label: A guide to landscape painting with Del Newport
